comments.commentBody: There is the most wonderful Kosher Deli restaurant on Third Avenue between E. 50th and 51st Street in New York, and its specialty is a splendid display of a variety of bagels.  The deli has a rich array of cream cheeses, and other combos, that would be hard to top elsewhere.  A friend of mine from Iraq of many decades, now retired and a former colleague in the international community, is possibly the best home chef I have ever met.  Fabulous at baking bread and pastries, she told me that a young relation who was visiting, had first plans in the morning to go in search of some bagels, and I reminded her of this great Kosher deli in our neighborhood.  We both agreed it is the best we have ever come across in over forty years here.
I meant 1940s, 1950s, and 1960s.

Quoted from op-ed: ". . .the history of business. Companies have achieved staggering productivity and vastly raised global living standards. . ."

This is a myth that should not be repeated over and over as if it is undeniable truth. Companies were guided in the 1940s, 1980s, and 1960s by reasonable government regulations and labor contracts that favored an equitable distribution of wealth which stimulated a long period of unprecedented consumer demand. These market forces fueled the engine of manufacturing and financial growth which allowed companies to achieve staggering productivity and vastly raise living standards. Mr. Kristoff, please repeat this over and over until the myth you've spouted in your op-ed is forever displaced from your repertoire of dangerous untruths.

There isn't much R&D and IP required to start a C2C ecommerce site like Taotao. The key is intimate understanding of local user's cultural habits.

Americans and their companies can keep on making these excuses: it won't get them any closer to success to China. On the other hand, witness Apple and GM: shining examples of great success and profits in China, because they make products, not excuses.

American firms didn't lose the China market - they were flat out denied it. As in a host of other industries, China's government put up structural impediments to foreign companies gaining market share, while actively favoring Chinese copycat companies with all means at its disposal. The Chinese government not only deliberately turned a blind eye to, but actively enabled (and continues to do so), the outright theft of intellectual property and trading in counterfeit goods in order to allow Chinese companies to "catch up" without having to invest hundreds of billions of dollars in their own R&D. Little wonder that companies like Alibaba, Huawei, Sinovel etc have been able to leapfrog Western competitors who are hobbled by minor matters like legality and property rights!

The only reason I hope Chinese companies will be somewhat successful in the US and Europe is that hopefully, that will increase the nexus with jurisdictions that enforce property and intellectual rights and therefore create a basis for significant legal and monetary reparations for these past thefts.

Alibaba is a game changer. They are as ingrained in China as Google is in the US and around the world. With yahoo owning 24% of alibaba, a US firm will get a windfall when they go public. Yahoo's stock will skyrocket and they'll use that stock currency to purchase other companies. Alibaba will partner with yahoo to Penetrate the US market and access its 700 million users.  Yahoo will then become the new social, content, ecommerce giant in china and of course Japan where they own big % of yhoo japan.

All these "Chinese versions of [insert someone else's idea here]" speak to the fact that China is bereft of its own ideas and has no true innovation. If it wasn't for their disregard for IP rights, they'd be up the Yangtze without a paddle.

The U.S. is different, in part because it shares a border with Mexico, a country whose mostly uneducated poor are desperate to come here for a better life. While Canada has its share of immigrants, those I've met are well-educated people who could afford to fly to Canada from China, Nigeria, etc., sometimes just as a steppingstone to the U.S., since Canada does not seem to have enough suitable jobs for even its best-qualified citizens, but getting into the U.S. through Canada is easier for some countries' citizens than coming here directly. Interesting, though, that the Canadians with whom I have worked, who viewed job opportunities here in the U.S. as preferable to what was available to them in Canada, have all been members of racial minorities or distinct ethnic groups. Perhaps that is just a coincidence, or maybe not.

Currently I am in my mid-30's and having read this article I would make some strong suggestions for those of you who are in my age bracket:

1) Begin saving NOW for retirement, whether it be through 401k's, 403b's, pensions, Roth IRAs, etc. There is absolutely no guarantee that social security will be around in 30 to 40 years assuming the whole country doesn't go bankrupt.

2) Do not become lifetime renters if you can help it otherwise prepare an strict budget and set aside at least 15-20% of your income into a savings account each year for use in retirement. This will mean cutting back on unnecessary expenses such as eating out at fancy restaurants.

3) If you are within reasonable means to purchase a house, consider either a town house or a single floor condominium. Single family homes become harder and costlier to maintain as you get older, plus they incur higher property tax rates. Condos on the other hand have useful amenities for seniors and/or disabled adults such as elevators. Understand as you get older climbing and descending flights of stairs become more difficult.

4) In this age of greater mobility, developing a strong network of friends and associates can be quite challenging especially in cities like New York where the general working population has become more transient, which is why it is always helpful to find a hobby or activity to keep yourself preoccupied when you retire.

5) Last but not least, hope for driver-less cars to come on the market!!!!

Thank you for noting Adam Smith's true views (as opposed to much abused meme about the "hidden hand" of the marketplace).  He also had a dim view of those who made money by acquiring capital rather than actually working (take note, oligarchs and opponents of the labor theory of economics).

E. Nowak,

If you substitute the word "Government" for the word "Corporations" in your first sentence your statement is equally true. You could also add that the primary purpose of "Government" is to collect taxes because without money "Government" on a large scale is impossible.

Neither example is inherently bad or good. The degree of either depend on the individuals in charge and the circumstances. Often with both upon looking back we see that we could have done better "if".
Don't forget our crooked Supreme Court, who should now have term limits.

Even the father of capitalistic philosophy, Adam Smith, believed in a regulated capitalism, not the laissez faire kind. He recognized even in that day that capitalists are in it for the money, not to look out for the common welfare, and he thought government should have the task of preventing possible abuses with regulatory measures.

What is striking about the present day is the extent to which corporations will go to prevent or circumvent regulations that affect them. They are reluctant to accept even quite reasonable restraints on their acquisitiveness. Some decades ago, it seemed that corporations, at least many of them, were willing to abide by some degree of regulation, but now it seems that any regulation whatever is to be fought tooth-and-nail.

Why the difference? Perhaps it's because union power, now practically non-existent, helped keep corporations in line and made them responsible partners in American industry. Or perhaps it was that Americans were better informed about the role of government vis a vis capitalism. And also Congress was not so beholden to corporate largesse to win elections then. But now the corporations, though not inherently evil, have increased their control over the country to the point of turning it into "corporate America," where they expect to call the political shots and won't brook any disagreement or interference in their plans to make more money.

I think religious pressure is worse, because it leads to loss of secular civilian control.  But otherwise, you're right, but add that bosses tend to be authoritarian in every case.  (Tend, means there are exceptions.)

Industry regulations, when carried out sensibly, are essential, especially when Companies (corporations, usually) selling a product look for the bottom line, profit, irrespective of the adverse consequences in the distant future. And Boehner and Cantor (and their ilk) know it, or should know it. This is political bluster, it is hypocritical, and allows the culprits to escape detection and, when discovered, immunity. This is shameful, damaging, and uncalled for in any sane society. When the price becomes too high at home, some Corporations have no second thoughts by selling a faulty or dangerous product abroad. Greed indeed, and unregulated. Is this responsible? Is this right?

And moving the army east risks triggering the Russian claim that Russian speakers are now being threatened/attacked, which is their supposed red line for invasion. And Ukraine's best units cannot seal the border because they cannot stop the Russian army.
